user_message:
<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 2.1 is: A project shall not contain unreachable code.

</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of OS_FileOpenCheck:
```c
int32 OS_FileOpenCheck(const char *Filename)
{
    int32                        return_code;
    OS_object_iter_t             iter;
    OS_stream_internal_record_t *stream;

    /* Check parameters */
    OS_CHECK_POINTER(Filename);

    return_code = OS_ERROR;

    OS_ObjectIdIterateActive(LOCAL_OBJID_TYPE, &iter);

    while (OS_ObjectIdIteratorGetNext(&iter))
    {
        stream = OS_OBJECT_TABLE_GET(OS_stream_table, iter.token);
        if (stream->socket_domain == OS_SocketDomain_INVALID && (strcmp(stream->stream_name, Filename) == 0))
        {
            return_code = OS_SUCCESS;
            break;
        }
    }

    OS_ObjectIdIteratorDestroy(&iter);

    return return_code;
}
```
</target_code>
<additional code>Here are the definitions of symbols that are related to the target function OS_FileOpenCheck:
#define OS_CHECK_POINTER(ptr) BUGCHECK((ptr)!=NULL,OS_INVALID_POINTER)
...
#define OS_ERROR (-1)
...
#define OS_SUCCESS (0)
...
int32 OS_ObjectIdIterateActive(osal_objtype_t objtype, OS_object_iter_t *iter)
{
    return OS_ObjectIdIteratorInit(OS_ObjectFilterActive, NULL, objtype, iter);
}
...
bool OS_ObjectIdIteratorGetNext(OS_object_iter_t *iter)
{
    OS_common_record_t *record;
    bool                got_next;

    got_next           = false;
    iter->token.obj_id = OS_OBJECT_ID_UNDEFINED;

    do
    {
        ++iter->token.obj_idx;
        if (iter->token.obj_idx >= iter->limit)
        {
            break;
        }

        record = OS_OBJECT_TABLE_GET(iter->base, iter->token);
        if (iter->match == NULL || iter->match(iter->arg, &iter->token, record))
        {
            iter->token.obj_id = record->active_id;
            got_next           = true;
        }
    } while (!got_next);

    return got_next;
}
...
void OS_ObjectIdIteratorDestroy(OS_object_iter_t *iter)
{
    OS_ObjectIdTransactionCancel(&iter->token);
}
...
#define OS_OBJECT_TABLE_GET(tbl, tok) (&tbl[OS_ObjectIndexFromToken(&(tok))])
...
OS_stream_internal_record_t OS_stream_table[OS_MAX_NUM_OPEN_FILES]
...
typedef struct
{
    char   stream_name[OS_MAX_PATH_LEN];
    uint8  socket_domain;
    uint8  socket_type;
    uint16 stream_state;
} OS_stream_internal_record_t
...
typedef struct
{
    OS_common_record_t * base;
    OS_ObjectMatchFunc_t match;
    void *               arg;
    osal_index_t         limit;
    OS_object_token_t    token;
} OS_object_iter_t
...
static inline osal_index_t OS_ObjectIndexFromToken(const OS_object_token_t *token)
{
    return token->obj_idx;
}
</additional code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
explanation: I focused on fragments that can affect control flow and potentially make code paths unreachable: the pointer check macro (OS_CHECK_POINTER) which expands to BUGCHECK (a failure handler that may not return), the iterator initialization/usage and its loop (OS_ObjectIdIterateActive / while (OS_ObjectIdIteratorGetNext(&iter)) plus the underlying OS_ObjectIdIteratorGetNext implementation which contains a do/while with an internal break), the iterator destroy call (which calls OS_ObjectIdTransactionCancel and could affect control flow), and the table-access macros/inline index function which determine how the iterator accesses array elements. These fragments are the points where non-returning calls, infinite loops, or unconditional jumps could make subsequent code unreachable and therefore need investigation for MISRA C 2023 Rule 2.1 compliance. Other lines in the provided function (initializations, assignment to return_code, the strcmp check, the final return, and the stream table declaration) are straightforward, follow normal control flow, and do not by themselves introduce unreachable code, so they do not need further investigation for this rule.
